sections.title: Gentle check-ups that build lifelong habits
sections.body: We keep appointments short, positive, and age-appropriate so children feel relaxed while we protect their growing smiles.
bullets: Calm examinations with tell-show-do and plenty of reassurance
Decay risk checks with fluoride and diet advice matched to age
Coaching for children and parents on brushing and home routines

sections.title: Care designed around young patients
items: Friendly, unhurried visits with the same calm clinicians where possible
Simple language and visuals to explain what will happen before we start
Age-appropriate fluoride guidance with no pushy product sales
Transparent advice for parents on diet, sugar frequency, and brushing
Clear next steps if we spot issues or need to monitor development

sections.title: Gentle exams with practical guidance
sections.body: Each visit is paced slowly so children stay comfortable while we check teeth, gums, and bite development.
bullets: Tooth, gum, and bite review with extra focus on erupting first molars
Decay risk assessment including grooves, early white spots, and diet habits
Oral hygiene coaching with brushing demonstrations and parent tips

sections.title: Simple steps we cover at every stage
items: Fluoride strength and varnish advice tailored to age and decay risk
Diet and sugar-frequency guidance with realistic swaps for snacks and drinks
Brushing habits: twice-daily routines, supervised brushing, and gentle technique
Fissure sealants discussed for deep grooves when they will genuinely help
Custom mouthguards and trauma tips for sports or active play
sections.strapline: Consistent, friendly reminders help children build habits that protect baby and adult teeth.

sections.title: Short, positive visits that build confidence
sections.body: We use tell-show-do, gentle pacing, and plenty of positive framing. Parents stay involved, and we pause whenever a child needs a breather.
sections.mediaHint: Calm, child-friendly pacing with familiar faces

sections.title: Support for growing smiles
items: First molars erupting with deep grooves that may trap plaque
Chipped or bumped teeth from sports or playground knocks
Early decay or white spots so we can act before fillings are needed
Thumb sucking, dummies, or mouth breathing that influence tooth position
Spacing and crowding patterns that may need orthodontic review

sections.eyebrow: When we suggest an orthodontic chat
sections.title: Early guidance keeps options open
sections.body: If we spot crowding, bite discrepancies, or habits affecting jaw growth, we’ll recommend an orthodontic assessment. We collaborate with orthodontic colleagues for fixed or removable options when the time is right—always explained clearly to families.
sections.mediaHint: Monitoring bite, spacing, and eruption patterns

faqs.question: When should my child first visit?
faqs.answer: We’re happy to see children as soon as their first teeth appear or by their first birthday. Early visits help them get used to the chair and let us spot any early issues.

faqs.question: How often should they come?
faqs.answer: Most children benefit from 6-monthly check-ups, but we may recommend shorter intervals if decay risk is higher or longer if everything is very stable.

faqs.question: Do baby teeth really matter?
faqs.answer: Yes. Healthy baby teeth guide adult teeth into place, support speech, and allow comfortable eating. Protecting them reduces the risk of pain, infection, or early tooth loss.

faqs.question: What if my child is scared?
faqs.answer: Tell us ahead of time and we’ll keep visits short, use tell-show-do, and let them stay in control. We can build up gradually with positive language and plenty of breaks.

sections.title: Book a gentle check-up for your child
sections.body: We’ll keep things calm, answer your questions, and map out a prevention plan that fits family life.
